description:
The academic advisory system is used to send emails to students regarding concerns or encouraging notes. These advisories are automatically copied to the instructor, student's advisors, and the Office of Academic Affairs. The Academic Affairs Committee keeps track of all advisories and the Associate Dean for Academic Affairs will meet with students who receive two or more advisories. Advisories can be used for concerns such as missing assignments or poor performance, but they can also be used to send positive notes about improvements or good exam performance. The advisory system can also be used to schedule conferences with students. Available to faculty and emeritus at HMC. The Academic Advisory System can be accessed by logging into the HMC Portal and looking in the Faculty tab.
Selecting a course takes you to a class list from which you can select one or more students. The next step allows you to enter any additional personalized comments and/or request a conference with the student(s). Finally, you’ll be able to preview the notices before they are sent.

CIS maintains campus-wide license agreements for popular academic software packages including MATLAB, Mathematica, Wolfram Alpha Pro, Maple and more. Installation and licensing information can be obtained by contacting the HMC Helpdesk. Users can install the software on their system or visit either of the CIS maintained computer labs in the LAC or Sprague first floor to use the software.

If you are taking a course at another campus and the professor is using software that HMC doesn’t license, the IT support group at that campus can help you obtain the software. Our HelpDesk can facilitate that request on your behalf if needed.

Additionally, the Academic & Research Computing Services (ARCS) group provides technical and advisory support for the following scientific software:

Mathematical Software: MATLAB, Mathematica, Maple, ODE Architect
Programming Software: Anaconda, Jupyter, Python packages
Statistical Software: R, RStudio, Tableau
Scientific and Engineering Software: COMSOL, Materials Studio, Gaussian, GROMACS
High Performance Computing Software/Library: MPI, OpenMP, GPGPU

We can also research new specialized (scientific) software on demand, and provide recommendations or “best effort” support on the selection and the use of new specialized software. We regularly provide seminars and workshops on some of the specialized scientific software. Available to faculty, students, and staff at HMC. Academic software packages are installed on all systems in CIS maintained computer labs. Our license also allows for installation on personal systems for HMC related use. Please visit our FAQ (Google Doc) for detailed installation and activation instructions for Maple, Mathematica, and Matlab. Please note that you can access Mathematica online and Matlab online.
Please contact the CIS Help Desk at 909.607.7777, send an email to helpdesk@hmc.edu, or chat with us online at helpdesk.hmc.edu if you need any further assistance with accessing any software.

Acrobat Pro DC is a software package that includes Acrobat desktop software, the Acrobat Reader mobile app with premium mobile features, and premium Adobe Acrobat online services. It offers various features such as productivity on the go, document scanning, creating protected PDFs, exporting PDFs to Office formats, integration with cloud storage services, signing forms from anywhere, and deleting sensitive information. However, it's important to note that while Acrobat Pro DC includes PDF and e-signing tools, it does not include Acrobat Sign, a more comprehensive e-signature service. Available to all faculty and staff at HMC. If you’d like a license, please email helpdesk@hmc.edu. Please note that if you only need to read PDF files, you can download Acrobat Reader, which is free to use.

Anki is a free, open source application that allows you to create flash cards in order to quickly memorize information. Both a desktop and mobile versions are available. You can also create an account on the Anki website that allows you to synchronize your flashcards between your desktop and mobile apps.
At HMC, faculty are very interested in learning the names and faces of all of the students in their classes. In order to support that CIS creates an Anki flash card file that contains the names and faces of all current HMC students. The cards are also tagged with the students’ class year, major, advisors, and state/country of origin. We do not include tags for courses due to FERPA concerns, but faculty are free to add their own tags.

[Anki](https://apps.ankiweb.net/) HMC faculty, staff and students can access this service, although it is primarily intended for faculty. To access this service please download the Anki file listed in the Related Links section below and follow the instructions in the Quick Guide to Installing Anki to install Anki and import the file.

CIS (Computing and Information Services) provides AV support for classes, meetings, and events on the HMC campus. To reserve an event space, use the EMS website. To request an AV setup, use the AV request form. Most classrooms and meeting rooms have built-in AV equipment. CIS maintains a list of AV equipment in class/meeting rooms. For on-campus meetings, CIS can provide additional equipment such as projectors, conference phones, laptops, and more. For large campus events, CIS can provide dedicated tech/AV support, sound systems, microphones, and video recording. CIS also offers training on campus AV equipment. Available to faculty and staff at HMC. If you would like to request an AV setup, please use our AV request form. CIS staff will respond within 24 hours confirming the event and what equipment and staffing will be provided.
To report a problem with audiovisual equipment, please contact the Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu or 909.607.7777.

A Bite of Learning is sponsored by the Harvey Mudd College Computing and Information Services Department in collaboration with the Library of The Claremont Colleges. The purpose of the lunchtime speaker series is to foster innovation in the use of technology in teaching, learning, and research. Presentations are informal with plenty of time for discussion and Q&A. Available to faculty, students and staff at HMC and all of The Claremont Colleges. CIS organizes and publicizes approximately six presentations per semester. The presentations are typically held in the Hoch Shanahan Aviation Room on the HMC campus from 12:15–1p.m. All faculty, staff and students of The Claremont Colleges are invited and are welcome to bring their lunches.
More information and a current schedule can be found on the A Bite of Learning Home Page. If you have an idea for a future presentation or would like to volunteer to present at A Bite of Learning please contact ehodas@hmc.edu.

Canvas is the Course Management System being adopted by all of The Claremont Colleges. All faculty and students teaching or enrolled in courses on Canvas have accounts on Canvas. Each college has their own instance of Canvas, but there is a Federated Trust between all instances that allows users to see any courses they might be enrolled in at any of the other colleges from their home instance of Canvas. More information on the instances of Canvas at The Claremont Colleges can be found here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/e/2PACX-1vTgMrNhWqMnEV6tqmR_xQr2V4f2RanhlBwBVK8R8aw-z0qOyilGX0AQ0834TbENqaRyngsfZvGPyxAp/pub. CIS provides support for Canvas, including help with accounts, passwords, consultation on tool usage, and training in workshops or one-on-one. Course sites are automatically created for all courses each semester and become available to faculty immediately. Students can see their courses up to two weeks before classes start if the instructor has published the site. If instructors want to combine course sections, they can contact the CIS Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu. Available to faculty, students, staff, and emeritus at HMC and all of The Claremont Colleges. To login to Canvas please use your HMC Credentials. Please send an email to helpdesk@hmc.edu to request Canvas support. A CIS staff member will respond within one business day.

At HMC, there are several Class and Meeting Rooms that contain different levels of classroom technology. A list of these rooms and their technology can be found here: [AV Equipment in HMC Class/Meeting Rooms](http://goo.gl/4Mj1Nx).

All classrooms in the Shanahan Center for Teaching and Learning (SCTL) have AV controls to enable a user to project from a VGA or HDMI source. [User Guides](https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B3M48dV5JsLVYUZqb2J4bGg1VDQ/view?usp=sharing) are provided in each room to aid in the use of the room.

SCTL Technology Rich Classrooms (SCTL 2450, 2454, 2460) allow the Academic & Research Computing Services Team (ARCS) to work with faculty and students on new technologies that we want to test at HMC. These rooms are designed to be flexible in their AV hardware, software, and control systems. If there are any technologies that you feel would be good to try in these rooms, please feel free to email the team at helpdesk@hmc.edu. Below are some additional technologies that can be found in these tech rich rooms.

[Smartboard](https://www.hmc.edu/cis/services/smartboard/)

[Wireless Projection – AppleTV (2454/2460) or MS WiDi adapter (2450)](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1iyswbxlkxtyMu0_tpUPNCSovaDcR5_aYAU6q694D7Gc/edit?usp=sharing)

Bluray/DVD player

Document Camera

Simulcast
Simulcasting is available in the SCTL Lecture Hall, Recital Hall, B460, and Technology Rich Classrooms. Simulcast is used to accommodate events too large for any single space by transmitting video and audio from one room to any number of the other simulcast capable rooms. Available to faculty, students, and staff at HMC.  View current list of rooms with known issues. You must reserve all event space via the Event Management System (EMS) – Facility Reservations system.
For help choosing a room, check the AV Equipment in HMC Class/Meeting Rooms for a list of rooms and technology contained within. (You will need to be logged in to g.hmc.edu to view this page).
For AV assistance with any of the rooms at HMC, please contact the CIS Help Desk (909.607.7777) or use the Audio Visual Request Form.

Account management is an important aspect of using Cognos reporting software. It involves assigning privileges, capabilities, and access to the software and its various features. To learn more about Cognos reporting software, click [here](https://www.ibm.com/products/cognos-analytics). Available to faculty, staff, and emeritus at HMC. Please contact the Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu for changes to your Cognos account.

service: Cognos Reporting: Training and Usage Support
description: Training and documentation are available to HMC faculty and staff Cognos users. [source] Available to faculty, staff, and emeritus at HMC. Individual appointments for training and support can be scheduled by contacting the Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu. Classes can be held for groups as needed. Basic vendor training is available within the Cognos site help menu as well.

Reporting assistance is available to help refine and compose reports in Cognos. CIS also accepts reporting requests by providing the output of requested reports, and publishing them so that they can be run in the future, or scheduled and output to emails. Some reporting requests require collaboration with other departments. Available to faculty, staff, and emeritus at HMC. Please contact the Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu for reporting assistance requests.

service: Cognos: Maintenance and Publishing of Metadata
description: Cognos is a reporting tool that can connect to many databases, but it is primarily used to report from CX, a Student Information System. Data is divided into packages and models for different departments, and these are published for users to use for reporting based on their security privileges. The structure, content, and organization of the packages are maintained by CIS. Modifications and new content can be added as needed. (source: [Link](https://example.com/)) Available to faculty, staff, and emeritus at HMC. If new data is needed, or changes to existing fields, please contact the Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu to create a support request.

The Sprague computer lab, located on the 1st floor of the Norman F. Sprague Center, contains 7 M1 24-inch iMacs and 5 Dell Optiplex PCs available for use on a first-come, first-serve basis. Systems in both labs are equipped with several academic software packages and applications used in courses. To request an application to be installed on the Mac and/or Windows platforms, please contact the CIS Help Desk. Available to faculty, students, staff, and emeritus at HMC. The Sprague lab is open 24/7 and are accessible after-hours via ID card swipe. All desktops can be authenticated with your HMC credentials.
To report a problem with computer lab software or hardware, please contact the Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu or 909.607.7777.

The CIS computer upgrade program at Harvey Mudd College is a source of new computer equipment. Its goals include standardizing equipment, providing adequate computing equipment to staff and faculty, refreshing equipment regularly, guiding departmental purchases, and potentially reducing costs. More details about the program can be found here: [Computer Upgrade Program](https://sites.google.com/g.hmc.edu/cis-cup/home). Available to faculty and staff at HMC. CIS is currently developing a database through which employees may look up their eligibility status. In the meantime, consult the CIS Help Desk to learn more about system eligibility.

CIS provides several different methods for emailing the instructors and students in a particular course. One option is using Google Groups. Another option is through the HMC portal, which allows faculty members to email all of the students in their class. Sakai also has an Email Archive tool that can create a mailing list. Available to faculty and emeritus at HMC. You can see all of the course mailing lists that you are a member of by going to Google Groups and clicking the My Groups link. Google Groups has a web interface to your course mailing lists which makes it easy to add and remove members and view archived messages. Any email client may be used to send mail to a Google Group.  If you are a faculty member teaching a course, then you are the owner of the course list and can make changes to the default settings. The default settings for a course mailing list are:
Only members of the group can see the list of members.
The web archive of messages sent to the group is turned off.
Prospective members must ask the owner of the list to be able to join.
We also have a list of all automatically generated course mailing lists on Google Groups (HMC login is required).
The HMC portal allows you to view all of your students (with photos) and email the class. The portal functions more as a one way faculty to student broadcast system, in that the students cannot mail to the class list via the portal.
The Sakai Email Archive tool allows you to email students and keeps a convenient searchable and sortable archive of the messages on the Sakai site. You can set up an address of your choice for the list, and configure the tool to allow email from any address or keep it closed. You do not have to be in Sakai to send messages, but can use the email client of your choice. Although the Email Archive tool is not part of the default set up for a course site, it is very easy to add, and can easily be configured to suit your needs. Anyone you have included in the site (eg. as an auditor) will be included in the recipient list. Even if you don’t use Sakai for anything else, it is worth considering the Email Archive tool for communicating with your class.

The Office of Communications and Marketing manages the core HMC website, which is used to promote the college. They use WordPress and work with department content editors to manage the website. If you want to place information on the main College website, consult with your department content editor.

CIS supports several other website hosting options:
- Sakai: for course or project sites that are fully supported and offer many tools.
- Google Workspace Sites: for creating easy-to-use websites for clubs, personal interests, or internal material.
- pages.hmc.edu: for providing static HTML sites.
- Dreamhost: a recommended option for developing active sites with languages like PHP, Python, or Ruby on Rails, or for personal WordPress blogs.

CIS can provide limited support for using Dreamhost. Available to faculty, students and staff at HMC. For questions or to request any of the services listed, including services provided by communications and marketing, please email helpdesk@hmc.edu.

CX software accounts can be created and managed [by assigning privileges, capabilities, and granting access](https://www.example.com/creating-managing-accounts) to CX and its various features. Available to faculty, staff, and emeritus at HMC. Supervisors can contact the Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu for CX account creation and changes. CIS can come install the software necessary to access CX for PCs, or a web interface can be used from either Mac or PC.

service: CX (Student Information System): Data Import and Export
description: Bulk updates can be imported and exported to/from CX. Examples: Communication between databases (Enrollment Manager, OnBase, PowerFaids) and from spreadsheets (Room Draw, Insurance Waivers). Available to faculty, staff, and emeritus at HMC. Please contact the Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu.

CX usage support includes installation and support of CX access software, such as [QuickMate/Putty](https://www1.quick-mate.com/) or [CX Web Interface 8.1](https://www.cms.gov/files/zip/cx810/index.html). CIS can also assist you in resolving problems with CX, and in modifications to CX menus and screens. Available to faculty, staff, and emeritus at HMC. Please contact the Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu.

A data management plan (DMP) is a document outlining how a researcher plans to manage data during and after a research project, including organization, maintenance, and sharing. Funding agencies now often require researchers to submit a formal DMP when applying for grants. The DMPTool is recommended for creating a DMP, and the Claremont Colleges Library provides resources on research data management. The library is also an institutional member of Dryad, a data repository that allows researchers to deposit datasets from any discipline at no cost. Dryad is one of many data repositories that can be used to share research data. Available to faculty, students, staff, and emeritus at HMC. Please feel free to contact The Claremont Colleges Library at library@claremont.edu for any help on using DMPTool or Dryad through an one-on-one session.

CIS supports the digital signs on the HMC campus using Chrome Sign Builder. A designated content manager is responsible for departmental digital signs after deployment. The signs can display various types of content such as today's menu items, news, and campus information. Available to faculty and staff at HMC. To inquire about a new sign, CIS recommends contacting Facilities and Maintenance to get the project started. Communicating with F&M ensures a TV can be mounted where you want to place a digital sign.
For assistance about current digital signs you may support, please contact the Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu

In accordance with the Dorm Network Resource Policy, students staying in the dorms have access to the HMC Network through wired (ethernet) ports and via wireless. The policy states that there is one wired port available per student in a dorm, but additional ports can be requested if needed. For better WiFi coverage or additional network ports, students can contact the CIS Help Desk for assistance. They can make changes to configurations, add temporary network equipment, or help set up personal network devices such as switches, routers, or access points. More information on recommended personal network devices can be found here: Recommended Personal Switches, Routers, and Access Points. Available to students at HMC. Wired: Connect an ethernet cable (cat5 or higher) into the port in your room. You will need to locate the ethernet ports in your room. They can sometimes be hidden behind furniture. Not all ports are active, but always start by trying the top left port first. If you have issues locating a working port please contact the CIS Help Desk.
Wireless: You will have access to the same wireless networks as you do already around campus. Please use Claremont-WPA for all your devices. For devices that do not support WPA2-Enterprise please use Claremont-ETC (reduced access but ideal for older devices and game consoles).
If you have any issues or questions please contact the Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu or 909.607.7777.

Eduroam (education wireless roaming) is a service that allows users from participating institutions to securely access the Internet from any Eduroam-enabled institution. Users can use their home institution credentials to access wireless networks at other institutions. The user's authentication is done by their home institution, while the authorization decision is made by the visited network. Available to faculty, students, staff, alumni, payers, emeritus, trustees, and applicants who have HMC credentials and visitors from other institutions who have Eduroam configured at their home institution. Access the appropriate wireless settings pane on the device to be connected and select the Eduroam network. When prompted, enter the appropriate <userid>@hmc.edu and password.
Please contact the Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu or909.607.7777 to request assistance with connecting to wireless networks.

CIS provides faculty, students, and staff at Harvey Mudd College with email accounts. Faculty and students use Google Workplace accounts for email, while staff use Microsoft 365 accounts. Alumni keep their G Suite accounts after graduation. Spam filtering is done with Cisco IronPort. There are multiple email addresses that can reach a user, depending on the service used. The HMC Email Flow diagram explains how mail is routed to different addresses. Available to faculty, students, staff, alumni, and emeritus at HMC. For G Suite users, please log into your HMC Gmail Account with your HMC Credentials.
For Microsoft 365 Users, please visit the Microsoft 365 login to access the Outlook Web App (OWA) or configure Outlook for Microsoft 365 on your system.
Please contact the Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu or 909.607.7777 to request support for these services.

File sharing allows users to collaborate, access and exchange files. CIS recommends the following options that are also self-service:

- [Google Drive](https://www.google.com/drive/) – A cloud storage solution from Google. Unlimited storage with your g.hmc.edu account. All current staff, faculty, emeriti, and alumni maintain access to their G Suite.

- [Sakai](https://www.sakailms.org/) – a course management and collaborative learning tool. This system serves faculty, staff and students of all seven Claremont Colleges and The Claremont Colleges Services. Available to faculty, students, staff, alumni, and emeritus at HMC and all of The Claremont Colleges. Please email helpdesk@hmc.edu to request file sharing support with Google Apps or Sakai.

"Footprints" is a ticket tracking system used by CIS to track help requests. Emailing helpdesk@hmc.edu will create a new ticket. After creation, an automated reply is sent via email from "HMC CIS Support" to notify the customer that a ticket has been created, and similarly for all updates to the ticket. Customers can send updates to tickets by replying to the generated emails. Notification is sent when a ticket has been closed with the opportunity for feedback through a survey. Available to faculty, students and staff at HMC. Tickets can be created by CIS.
Tickets are generated when an email is sent to helpdesk@hmc.edu.
Submitting a Help Desk Request Form, Laptop Reservation Request, or AV Request Form also generates a ticket.
Requests for after hours support must be made at least 1 week in advance

CIS offers Formstack, an online form builder for creating various types of online forms. However, they no longer create new accounts in Formstack. Available to faculty, staff, and emeritus at HMC. Visit the Formstack website. Formstack uses its own standalone credentials. Please send an email to helpdesk@hmc.edu to request Formstack support.

Google’s G Suite includes access to additional apps that can be turned on to obtain additional functionality. Some are free and some involve payment. Some can be turned on by individual users and some have to be turned on at an administrator level. The Google Apps Marketplace provides access to apps that add extra functionality to existing Google Apps such as Docs, Drive, or Gmail. These can allow you to sort a Google Sheet by cell color, or add mathematics equations and graphs to a Google Doc, for example. There are also some apps that must be activated by an administrator for the whole campus. Some examples of apps that CIS has activated using this method are Google Plus and Kissflow. CIS’s process for apps that require administrator activation is as follows: 1. We receive an activation request. 2. We test the app in production (usually testing involves at least CIS, but may include others) 3. We tell people we are going to turn on a new app. 4. We turn the app on. 5. We wait for concerns to be raised, if any. Available to Faculty, Students, Staff, Alumni, and Emeriti at HMC. Please contact the Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu or 909.607.7777.

CIS provides Google Workplace accounts to faculty, staff, students, and alumni of HMC. [Google Workplace](https://workspace.google.com/) includes Gmail, Google Calendar, Google Drive, Google Sites and more! Available to Faculty, Students, Staff, Alumni, and Emeriti at HMC. HMC G Suite accounts can be accessed by visiting HMC Google Workplace. Enter your HMC Credentials username and password at the identity provider login screen. An HMC Credentials username followed by @g.hmc.edu should be used when logging in to an HMC G Suite account within an application.
Please send an email to helpdesk@hmc.edu to request G Suite support.

HMC uses Google Groups for both automated and non-automated mailing lists. They have been creating new ad hoc lists in Google Groups for several years and have started creating automated lists such as Course, Major, Dorm, and Class year lists. They also have a list of all automatically generated course mailing lists on Google Groups. Google Groups allows users to create online and email-based groups for engaging in discussions, organizing events, and finding people with similar interests. Users can access group posts through email or the online interface. For more information, there are helpful videos on finding and joining Google Groups and emailing class and departmental lists using Google Groups. Available to faculty, students, staff, alumni, and emeritus at HMC. Visit our Google Groups home page.
Please send an email to helpdesk@hmc.edu to request support regarding creating or modifying a mailing list.

Gradescope is an online grading platform that offers faster, more consistent, and fairer grading. Faculty and students at HMC can sign up for free accounts, thanks to the institutional license. Faculty also have access to premium features such as flexible rubrics, autograding of programming assignments, grouping similar answers, and integration with Sakai. [Gradescope](https://www.gradescope.com/) HMC Faculty and Students can access this service. Detailed instructions for faculty for adding Gradescope to your Sakai site, creating a Gradescope course site, and creating assignments are available in the documentation below. Instructions for students are also available below.

Hard drive encryption uses cryptographic algorithms to secure data on a hard drive. Data on an encrypted hard drive cannot be read by anyone who does not have access to the system, appropriate key, or password. Encryption is best used on machines that can easily be lost or stolen. At HMC, CIS recommends encrypting your entire operating system volume through BitLocker for Windows computers, or FileVault for Apple computers. You will be given a unique recovery key during the encryption setup process. This key is needed to decrypt your hard drive if BitLocker or FileVault locks your system. BitLocker may activate on your system if there is an unexpected power outage, if you are replacing hardware components in your computer, or if you unplug your computer and move it to a different location. In those scenarios, you will need the recovery key to decrypt your data. Please save your key somewhere safe (i.e., not on your computer). CIS recommends Google Drive, which is encrypted on Google’s servers, or any encrypted password manager, such as LastPass at HMC. Available to faculty, students, and staff at HMC. Configuration of these applications can vary from system to system, but at its simplest:
Bitlocker requirements:
Windows 10 or 11 (Pro, Enterprise, and Education editions) 
Trusted Platform Module (TPM) – special microchip in most newer Windows computers
FileVault requirements:
Mac OS X 10.7 (Lion) or higher
The CIS Help Desk can assist all users with turning on hard drive encryption.
You can find Instructions on how to do this yourself on Microsoft’s and Apple’s websites:
Turn on device encryption
Use FileVault to encrypt your Mac
Encrypt Mac data with FileVault

CIS helps faculty and students find on and off-campus resources for High Performance Computing (HPC) needs in their research and teaching. The [ACCESS](https://access-ci.org/) is an NSF-funded project that gives access to a network of supercomputers located at institutions across the United States. CIS Academic and Research Computing Services (ARCS) team provides the following services:
Selecting the appropriate HPC resource.
Getting allocations on the computing resources made available by ACCESS.
Setting up the computing environment and workflow.
[HPC Resources at Harvey Mudd College](https://www.hmc.edu/cis/hpc-at-hmc/) outlines other computing resources available at the college. For more information, please email the CIS Help Desk at [helpdesk@hmc.edu](mailto:helpdesk@hmc.edu). Available to faculty, students and staff at HMC. To access the service, please contact the CIS Help Desk (helpdesk@hmc.edu, x77777, 909.607.7777).

With the launch of its Identity and Access Management (IAM) initiative, the CIS at Harvey Mudd College introduced the concept of "HMC Credentials" - the combination of a user's HMC User ID and HMC Password. As the initiative progresses, more systems will start using HMC credentials. A list of services currently using HMC credentials can be found here. Going forward, CIS will no longer refer to local account credentials unless they differ from HMC credentials. Some services that use HMC credentials can be accessed via Single Sign-On (SSO), allowing users to log in once to access all other SSO services. CIS staff will never ask for the password associated with HMC credentials. Users can reset their HMC password here. Available to faculty, students, staff, alumni, payers, emeriti, trustees, and applicants at HMC. When you are granted HMC Credentials for the first time, you will receive an email at the non-HMC address that you provided. The email contains instructions about how to set up your HMC Credentials password and security questions.

iClickers are a personal response system that can be used for a variety of purposes in the classroom. They use a wireless receiver to record student votes, and software on the instructor's laptop records and displays the votes. Students can receive points for participation and correctness of their responses. Grading information can be exported and uploaded into Sakai. Faculty can check out iClickers from CIS for the semester or a single class. CIS also provides training and software installation and configuration. ARCS can provide consultations on incorporating iClickers into syllabi. For more information, visit the iClickers website. Faculty, students and staff at HMC can check out sets of 50 iClickers from the CIS Help Desk, as well as the wireless base stations. For large lecture classes, students may be asked to rent or purchase their own iClickers from Huntley Bookstore, in which case faculty can just check out the wireless base stations they need. CIS will usually send an email to the faculty several weeks before classes start to inquire if they want to use the iClickers in a class. Faculty can also send email to the CIS Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu if they are interested in trying out the iClickers in a class. It’s helpful if faculty can give us the following information when requesting the iClickers and/or wireless base stations:
Course name and number
When does class meet?
Where does class meet?
How many students are in the class?

Kuali Build is a code-free, cloud-based SaaS application development platform with business process management functionality. It allows users to create their own forms and workflows using powerful, automated, integrated business applications. Kuali can collect feedback and information, notify users, create approval pathways, and enable a responsive user experience. Available to faculty, students, staff, alumni, payers, emeriti, trustees, and applicants at HMC. When you are granted HMC Credentials for the first time, you will receive an email at the non-HMC address that you provided. The email contains instructions about how to set up your HMC Credentials password and security questions.

service: Lab Software in CIS Managed Labs and Carts

description: CIS manages three laptop carts with a total of 30 laptops. Each cart contains 10 laptops. The laptops are macOS based systems and are configured in the same manner as CIS Lab Systems. Here is a link to a list of all software loaded on the laptops. CIS tries their best to meet all requests and have been successful so far because faculty have been flexible with the quantity of laptops requested. In addition to the carts, there are three laptops dedicated to the Technology Rich Classrooms (SCTL 2450, 2454, 2460) for instructor use. Available to faculty and staff at HMC. To reserve a cart for your class, please use this Laptop Cart Reservation Request Form or email helpdesk@hmc.edu with your request. Please expect confirmation of your request within 2 school days.

LastPass is a cloud-based password manager that allows users to store website credentials, notes, and other data in a secure and convenient manner. You can use LastPass to generate and store a complex password for your HMC credentials, or any other logins you use for Mudd or non-Mudd related services. [LastPass](http://www.lastpass.com/) [HMC credentials](https://www.hmc.edu/cis/services/hmc-credentials/) LastPass Business is an opt-in service available to all HMC available to faculty and staff for work-related university usernames and passwords.
LastPass Premium is an opt-in service available to all HMC students, alumni, as well as any faculty or staff wanting a personal account.
Please refer to our HMC LastPass FAQ to understand the differences between LastPass Business, Premium, and Free. LastPass Business (for faculty and staff)
Data stored in LastPass can be accessed via the LastPass website, a browser plugin, or the various LastPass for Mobile applications. Duo two-factor authentication is required upon sign in.
You will receive an email from do-not-reply-support@lastpass.com that contains your activation code. If you are a new employee, please periodically check your inbox for the activation email once your @hmc email is created. If you need your LastPass invite resent to you, please use our HMC LastPass self-service portal. Please contact helpdesk@hmc.edu if you are unable to activate your account.
You can optionally link a personal LastPass account (a Free or Premium account using a non-HMC email) to keep personal passwords separate from your work passwords. You can upgrade your personal account to Premium using the information below.
LastPass Premium (for students, alumni, and any faculty or staff wanting a personal Premium account)
As with our Business users, data stored in LastPass can be accessed via the LastPass website, a browser plugin, or the various LastPass for Mobile applications.
You can upgrade your personal LastPass account to Premium by visiting our Harvey Mudd LastPass Premium page. In the field asking for the university email address, please enter your HMC email address in the format username@hmc.edu. Any personal email address (e.g., Gmail, Yahoo) can be used to sign up. If you have any trouble accessing your HMC email, please contact helpdesk@hmc.edu.
We do not manage Premium accounts. If you forget your Master Password or have any other account issues, please refer to LastPass support.

CIS uses the Mediasite lecture capture system to record audio and video of speakers as well as screen capture of presentations. The recordings are distributed through the course management system Sakai, unless otherwise requested. Lecture capture is available in various classrooms on campus, including the Shanahan Center and Galileo Auditoria. The recordings are stored on Mediasite's servers until the end of the semester, at which point they are moved into USS's video archive on Google Drive. If you need a video hosted for more than two semesters, USS can help transfer it to Google Drive. Other features of Mediasite include the ability to embed questions, search for specific sections, and customize the player layout. Available to faculty and staff at HMC. Students who require lecture capture for academic accommodations can reach out to the ADA/Title IX coordinator. Faculty can request lecture capture recording by using our AV Request Form or by sending an email to helpdesk@hmc.edu. CIS can schedule automated recording of every class session or individual class meetings. Staff can also request lecture capture recording of training sessions or other events. The recordings are automatically uploaded to the Mediasite hosted site and can be distributed either through a public URL or through a link in a Sakai or Canvas site.
Faculty who are requesting lecture capture recording of every class session should coordinate with the Registrar to make sure their class is scheduled to meet in one of our lecture capture-ready classrooms (Galileo Pryne, Galileo McAlister, Galileo Edwards, Shanahan 1430 (Lecture Hall), Shanahan B480 (Recital Hall), B442, B460, 2450, 2454, 2460, and 3460).
While students cannot directly request lecture capture from CIS, students who require lecture capture for academic accommodations can reach out to the ADA/Title IX coordinator.

The CIS Help Desk at Harvey Mudd College offers a variety of equipment for short-term loans to faculty, staff, and students. This includes Mac and PC laptops, tablets, iPads, video cameras, flash drives, and presentation equipment. This equipment can be requested for academic and administrative work, as well as for exploring new technology for instructional purposes and presentations. (Link: [CIS Help Desk](https://www.hmc.edu/cis/services/cis-help-desk/)) Available to faculty, staff, and students at HMC. If you’d like to request a loaner, please email helpdesk@hmc.edu describing your loaner request.

CIS offers Microsoft 365 accounts to staff for e-mail and calendaring, which provide similar functionality as a traditional Exchange account. These accounts can be added to Outlook and the web interface can be accessed from most browsers and mobile devices. Microsoft 365 being a cloud-based service allows easy access from anywhere. Available to faculty, staff and students at HMC. Log in to Microsoft 365 with your email address and HMC Credentials password. Please call or send an email to helpdesk@hmc.edu to request Microsoft 365 support.

Harvey Mudd College uses Microsoft 365, which gives students access to Microsoft 365 Education for Students. It allows access to the Microsoft Office Suite of Applications for free to students who are enrolled at HMC. Available to students at HMC. Visit Microsoft 365 for Students and verify eligibility by using your HMC email address.

The Mudd Shots website, which features student photos for each dorm and graduating year at Harvey Mudd College (HMC), has been moved to the HMC Portal. The new version of Mudd Shots now includes photos of non-HMC students who are registered for the course. These additional photos are meant to help students and faculty familiarize themselves with the names and faces of other students. Available to faculty, students, and staff at HMC. The Mudd Shots website pages are restricted by IP address so you must either use a wired ethernet connection on the HMC campus or VPN in order to view them.

HMC distinguishes between legal name changes and campus name changes. Students, faculty, and staff who wish to change their legal name or campus name should contact the Registrar's Office or the Human Resources Office. The necessary changes will be made across all system accounts, though some systems may require manual updates. CIS does not typically change usernames, but a username change can be requested if a legal name change makes it necessary. Available to Faculty, Staff, and Students. Students should contact the Registrar’s Office. Faculty and Staff should contact the Human Resources Office.

Ninjio is a cybersecurity awareness training solution that uses short videos and infographics to educate people about security topics. It aims to increase awareness and promote safe computing both at work and at home. You can learn more about Ninjio [here](https://www.ninjio.com/). Available to faculty and staff at HMC. Ninjio sends an email with a link to an animated story-based video about different security topics. Please contact the Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu if you have questions.

service: OnBase: Troubleshooting and Maintenance of HMC Solutions (excluding RFC)
description: Maintenance and troubleshooting services for existing HMC solutions (excluding RFCs) can be accessed here. Additionally, users can make necessary additions or modifications to functionality, users, document types, and keywords as required. Available to faculty and staff at HMC. Please contact the Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu for assistance with using OnBase.

Assigning privileges, capabilities, and access to HMC OnBase software and its various features (excluding RFC use). Available to faculty and staff at HMC. OnBase access is granted with the implementation of a solution for a department and purchase of licenses. Security and privileges can be modified by a System Administrator, and requests should be sent to the helpdesk. OnBase can be installed in a myriad of ways depending on the needs of the users. OnBase has a desktop software (the Unity Client) that can be installed by CIS, or it can be accessed using a supported web browser.
You will need to connect to the Harvey Mudd VPN before using OnBase.

OnBase is a software platform used for developing and implementing business process solutions. It is designed to streamline and automate business processes, such as document management, workflow management, and content management. With OnBase, businesses can improve efficiency, reduce costs, and increase productivity. To learn more about OnBase, visit their official website. Available to faculty and staff at HMC. OnBase access is granted with the implementation of a solution for a department and purchase of licenses. Security and privileges can be modified by a System Administrator, and requests should be sent to the helpdesk. OnBase can be installed in a myriad of ways depending on the needs of the users. OnBase has a desktop software (the Unity Client) that can be installed by CIS, or it can be accessed using a supported web browser.

service: OnBase: Training and Usage Support for HMC Solutions (excluding RFC)
description: Training for the use of OnBase software is available for departments with an OnBase solution in place. Installation and overviews of the different clients, demonstrations on different features, and becoming familiar with the OnBase environment are all available. More information can be found here: [OnBase training](https://www.onbase.com/en/training). Available to faculty and staff at HMC. Please contact the Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu for assistance with using OnBase. Many videos and demonstrations for using OnBase are also available through OnBase Training (any OnBase user at HMC can create accounts at this site. Reference The Claremont Colleges Services in your account creation request).

Online form builders like Kuali and Google Forms allow users to create and deliver web-based forms. However, CIS will no longer support the third-party service Formstack after August 2023. They are offering help in training and transferring forms from Formstack to Kuali. In general, they recommend using Google Forms for simple surveys on campus, while Kuali is better for forms that display information from HMC data sources or require extensive form logic. For formal academic research, they suggest purchasing an account with Qualtrics or another survey tool provider. Additionally, users need to be mindful of FERPA compliance when storing and sharing data from online forms. Available to faculty, students, staff, alumni, and emeritus at HMC. To use Google Forms, login to HMC Google Workplace website, then navigate to Forms using the Apps menu in the top-right corner. You may need to click the “More” button at the bottom of the menu to see Forms.
To use Kuali, visit the Kuali Build website. Kuali uses the HMC credentials. Please send an email to helpdesk@hmc.edu to request Kuali support.

Lynda.com is an online video library of courses for business, technology and creative skills. Mudd faculty, students and staff may find courses on web accessibility, Linux, Advanced Excel or Github of interest. Lynda is available to HMC faculty, students, and staff through both the Los Angeles County Public Library (e.g. Claremont branch) and the Los Angeles City Public Library. Note: All LA County Library locations, including the Claremont public library, are closed until further notice due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Please refer to the LA County Library Coronavirus Update page for more information. You must first sign up for a free library card at the Claremont Public Library. We recommend you apply for a digital library card instead of a physical card, as you will still receive a library card number and PIN and can use that to access Lynda.com. Otherwise, if you need a physical card, print and fill out the physical form and bring identification when you turn it in at any LA Country Library with sidewalk service. Students, if you have a California driver’s license, that will work. Otherwise the combination of your current student ID and an out of state driver’s license (or passport) will work. Once you have a digital or physical library card, head to the LA County Library Lynda portal and enter your library card number and PIN.

OpenDNS Umbrella is a network security service recently purchased by the Claremont Colleges. It redirects users to a warning page if they attempt to connect to a known malicious site. It examines requests from devices to determine if a site is malicious and redirects to a benign page if it is. It helps with issues such as botnets, ransomware, phishing, and 'drive-by-download' attacks. More information can be found in the article "Enterprise Threat Detection Like no Other" (https://www.opendns.com/enterprise-security/threat-enforcement/). Available to faculty, students, staff, alumni, payers, emeritus, trustees, and applicants at HMC. All campus devices that connect to the wireless network or to the HMC wired network using DHCP will be automatically protected. Please contact the Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu or 909.607.7777 if you are unsure if your system is currently protected by OpenDNS Umbrella.

Pages.hmc.edu is a server maintained by CIS where HMC faculty, students, and staff can host static HTML web pages. [1] Available to faculty, students, staff, and emeritus at HMC. Please send an email to helpdesk@hmc.edu.

The Rapid Identity Portal allows users to manage their HMC Credentials. The RI Portal provides options to reset or change your password and set up security questions in case of forgetting your password. Learn more about the Rapid Identity Portal [here](https://www.examplelink.com). Available to faculty, students, staff, alumni, payers, emeritus, trustees, and applicants at HMC. Visit the Rapid Identity Portal.
You can also follow this step by step guide for resetting your password.

Piazza is a popular alternative to the Sakai Forums tool with a lot more functionality. Its main use is as a tool for managing student questions. Students can work collaboratively to answer both student- and instructor-posed questions. You can also create announcements and quick polls as well as post content to the Resources section. HMC recently purchased a site license for Piazza. (Source: [here](https://www.hmc.edu/cis/student-computing/piazza/)) HMC faculty, staff, and students all have access to Piazza. Faculty and students can create Piazza accounts by going to directly to the Piazza login page. We recommend using your username@hmc.edu email address for your account. Faculty can then create their Piazza class sites through the Piazza website.
However, we recommend using the Sakai Piazza tool that allows faculty to link their Sakai course site to their Piazza class. The tool will automatically create a Piazza class site and will also create Piazza accounts for those who don’t already have them. See below for links to documentation for faculty and students.

The HMC Portal is a web browser-based platform used by faculty, students, and staff at Harvey Mudd College (HMC) to view and modify CX data. CX is the enterprise information system used by HMC and other undergraduate Claremont Colleges for storing and managing student and college data. Faculty can use the Portal to view class lists, manage permissions for adding classes, submit grades, monitor advisees, and submit academic advisories. Portal accounts for incoming students are created in early June. To access the Portal, log in with HMC credentials and click on the 'Faculty' tab. Grades can be entered using the 'My Courses' portlet, and the 'Advisee Roster' portlet is located to the right. Use the links and navigation tools on the Portal instead of the browser's 'back,' 'forward,' and 'refresh' buttons. Further assistance is available by clicking on the question mark and utilizing the wrench icon for portlet preferences. Available to faculty at HMC. Go to the portal login page. You can login using your standard HMC Credentials username and password.
Mobile devices are not currently supported by the HMC Portal.
Please note that this service requires cookies. See the related links below on how to ensure that cookies are being accepted for login.

The HMC Portal is a web-based platform that allows students, faculty, and staff to access certain data from the CX enterprise information system used by HMC and other Claremont Colleges. It provides features such as course registration, grade viewing, and bill payment for students, and course and advisee information viewing for faculty. Requests for portal improvements are reviewed by the Portal Advisory Group. These improvements can include adding approved links, new portlets, local modifications, and syncing the portal with cross registration updates from the other 5C institutions. Available to faculty, students, staff, payers, and emeritus at HMC. Please contact the Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu or 909.607.7777 for HMC portal support.

The HMC Portal is a web platform that allows faculty, students, and staff to view and modify CX data. CX is the enterprise information system used by HMC and the other undergraduate Claremont Colleges. The Portal provides various features for students, such as course registration, managing student accounts, viewing grades, unofficial transcripts, and degree information. Portal accounts for new students are created in June of the year they enroll. To access grade information, students can log into the Portal using their HMC credentials and click on the 'Student' tab. The 'Course Registration' tab allows students to search for classes and register for courses. The 'Student Account Info' tab provides access to current account balances and payment services. When using the Portal, it is advised to use the site's links and navigation tools instead of the browser's buttons to avoid losing any unsaved progress. Additional help can be found by clicking on the question mark or wrench icon on the site. Available to students at HMC. Go to the Portal login page. You can login using your standard HMC Credentials username and password.
Mobile devices are not currently supported by the HMC Portal.
Please note that this service requires cookies. See the related links below on how to ensure that cookies are being accepted for login.

Harvey Mudd College offers unlimited free printing for all students. Students can print remotely to any of the four designated printers on campus using the PaperCut print management system. They can use the Mobility Print or Web Print options to print on campus. Faculty and staff departments have their own dedicated or shared networked printers supported by CIS. While some people choose to install a personal printer, it is not necessary due to the numerous printers provided by CIS. Available to faculty, students, and staff at HMC. Student Printing
Please follow our HMC Student Printing setup guide to use our student printers.
Faculty and Staff Printing
For assistance with the installation of faculty or staff printers, please contact the CIS Help Desk at 909.607.7777 or helpdesk@hmc.edu.

Research computing support provides services to the HMC community on high-performance computing, high-throughput computing, large scale data storage resources and other advanced digital services related to faculty and student research.

Academic and Research Computing Services (ARCS) oversees research computing services, working closely with faculty and students on their use of advanced computing resources and digital services. The Scientific Computing Specialist is Harvey Mudd College’s ACCESS Campus Champion and provides expert support for accessing and utilizing high-performance computing, high-throughput computing, and data-driven computing resources on national supercomputer centers through ACCESS and on cloud computing platforms such as AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud.

To help your research activities, we…

Suggest the right resources through one-on-one consultations: [hyperlink](https://www.hmc.edu/academic-and-research-computing-services/consultation/)

Provide workshops and training for scientific computing tools: [hyperlink](https://www.hmc.edu/academic-and-research-computing-services/workshops-and-events/)

Introduce emerging research computing resources: [hyperlink](https://www.hmc.edu/academic-and-research-computing-services/research-computing-resources/)

Plan the College’s research computing capacity for the future: [hyperlink](https://www.hmc.edu/academic-and-research-computing-services/research-computing-resources/) Available to faculty, students, staff, and emeritus at HMC. For more information, questions, and requests about Research Computing, please email the HMC ARCS group (arcs-l@g.hmc.edu) or helpdesk@hmc.edu.

Sakai is the Course Management System used by all of The Claremont Colleges. All faculty and students, and most staff, have accounts on Sakai. There is a single instance of Sakai which is managed by Pomona College. CIS provides support for Sakai including help with accounts and passwords as well consultation on how and when to use specific Sakai tools, help on how to use specific tools, and training on Sakai in the form of workshops and one-on-one training.
Sakai accounts for incoming students are generally created at the beginning of June when the various Sakai sites for incoming students become available. Course sites are created automatically for all courses each semester and become available to students two weeks before classes start. A full description of our policies regarding the creation of course sites and populating them with students and faculty is described in our Sakai Policy document.
Sakai course sites are created for each individual section of a course. If the instructor wishes to combine all or some of the sections into one site, please send an email to the CIS Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu. Available to faculty, students, staff, and emeritus at HMC and all of The Claremont Colleges. If you are not sure if you have a Sakai account or have forgotten your password, please contact the Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu or 909.607.7777.
Please send an email to helpdesk@hmc.edu to request Sakai support. A CIS staff member will respond within one business day.

The Smartboard is an interactive display that allows users to work on digital content using their fingertips and digital markers. Everything written and imported on the whiteboard software can be captured and reused later. CIS has a SMART Board 8070i with fully integrated Smartboard technology and whiteboard software. The CIS Academic and Research Computing Services team works with faculty members on logistics and demos for using the Smartboard in a classroom. You can find more information on the Smartboard here: [link to more information on the Smartboard] Available to faculty, students, and staff at HMC. To access this service, please contact the Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu or 909.607.7777. We recommend that you meet with an ARCS staff member before using either the Smarboard in a class or meeting.

To reduce spam and viruses, HMC utilizes several levels of email filtering. Cisco IronPort scans incoming emails sent to @hmc.edu addresses. Google Workplace and Microsoft 365 also automatically filter emails. Trend Micro Agents are used on CIS Managed systems to provide threat protection for malware, device control, and more. Available to faculty, students, staff, alumni, emeritus, and trustees at HMC. Each morning IronPort sends every user an e-mail with the subject line “Claremont Colleges Spam Digest”. This e-mail will have a summary of all recent quarantined messages. To get a complete list of quarantined messages a user can click on “View all Quarantined Messages” to log into your IronPort Quarantine. This link will change from time to time, so it’s best practice to use the link from your newest digest e-mail. You may also manage your “Safelist” and “Blocklist” when visiting your Quarantine.
Microsoft 365 places quarantined email in a folder called “Junk E-Mail” and Google Mail places it in a folder called “Spam.”
For Trend Micro, you system should already have the Trend Micro Agent installed on your CIS Managed system. If it is not, please contact the CIS Help Desk.
Please contact the CIS Help Desk for additional support with spam and virus filtering.

Trend Micro is an anti-virus program selected by HMC's CIS department for faculty and staff use. It can be installed on Windows or macOS by either the Help Desk or the user. Available to faculty and staff. Trend Micro is available to download and install through a Shared Drive on Google:
macOS installer
Windows installer
You will need to log in using your HMC credentials to access the installers. Please contact the Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu or 909.607.7777 to request assistance with installing or accessing Trend Micro.

VPN (virtual private network) can be used to access internal resources from off-campus. Nowadays, VPN is required for only a few services, used by a small number of people: 
- On-premise file servers/shares (e.g., TempStorage)
- Financial Aid PowerFAIDs
- Cognos
- OnBase
- CX Servers

Please note that VPN is not needed to access [The Claremont Colleges Library resources](https://colleges.tccd.edu/academics/library/), [Google Workplace](https://workspace.google.com/), [HMC email resources](https://www.hmc.edu/its/email/), [the Portal](https://my.hmc.edu/), [Sakai](https://sakai.claremont.edu/portal), or [Workday](https://www.workday.com/). Available to all faculty, students, staff, and emeritus at HMC. To log in, please follow these steps:
Connect to vpn.claremont.edu
Select “Harvey Mudd College” from the Group drop-down menu
Enter your HMC credentials in the Rapid Identity login window
Approve the Duo prompt
For more detailed steps with screenshots, please refer to this guide.
If you have the Cisco AnyConnect application installed already, you can upgrade your client by connecting to vpn.claremont.edu and approving the prompts to update your client.
If you do not have the VPN client already installed, you will need to download the Cisco AnyConnect application from this Google Drive folder.

In accordance with the college’s Accessibility Policy, faculty, students and staff can request assistance from the Academic and Research Computing Services group in CIS with making their web pages and other documents accessible. The [CIS ARCS group](https://www.cis.cmc.edu/cis-service/catalog/153) can provide the following services:

- Consulting to faculty and staff regarding the use of specific tools recommended by ARCS
- Consulting on instructional design
- Consulting regarding the Claremont Colleges Learning Management System, [Sakai](https://www.cis.cmc.edu/cis-service/catalog/21) This service is available to all HMC faculty, staff and students. To request help with making web pages and other documents accessible please send an email to the CIS Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu.

Claremont-WPA is the preferred wireless network at HMC, offering WPA2-Enterprise security and access to internal resources. Authentication requires HMC credentials. For Android devices, additional information may be needed. Eduroam allows users from participating institutions to access secure networks using their HMC credentials. Authentication with HMC credentials is required, and visiting users must enter their home campus credentials. Claremont-ETC is for older devices and guests who can't use Eduroam. It is less secure and requires a shared password. HMC users can request the password, while non-HMC users must contact the CIS Help Desk. The list of participating institutions can be found at Eduroam's website. Claremont-WPA and Claremont-ETC are available to faculty, staff, students, emeritus, and trustees at HMC and all of The Claremont Colleges.
Eduroam is also available to all those previously listed as well as visitors from other institutions who have Eduroam configured at their home institution.
Guests who do not have access to Eduroam should contact the Help Desk for the Claremont-ETC password. Access the appropriate wireless settings pane on the device to be connected and select the appropriate network for the use case. When prompted, enter the appropriate username and password.
Please contact the Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu or 909.607.7777 to request assistance with connecting to wireless networks. A CIS staff member will respond within one business day.  Or, if you prefer, you can use our form to Submit a request for wireless help

Wireless Projection allows users to display content from their devices to a projection or LCD screen without the use of cables. This provides freedom of movement and the ability to easily share screen access. AppleTVs and Microsoft WiDi adapters are currently available in select rooms on campus for wireless projection. The list of equipped rooms can be found on the AV Equipment in the HMC Class/Meeting Rooms page. Instructions for using the Wireless Display devices can be found here: SCTL Wireless Projection Instructions and Hoch-Shanahan Wireless Projection Instructions. Available to faculty, students, and staff at HMC. To schedule a one-on-one demonstration on how to use the Wireless Projection devices, please contact the Help Desk at helpdesk@hmc.edu or 909.607.7777.

Workday is a Software as a Service (SaaS) platform used at all eight institutions of The Claremont Colleges (TCC) for financial accounting and human resources. [Link](https://www.workday.com/en-us/homepage.html) Available to faculty, staff, and emeritus who have had accounts created. Workday uses HMC Credentials to authenticate after selecting Harvey Mudd College from the drop down.
If you have difficulty logging in or getting access to Workday, please contact the CIS Help Desk at: helpdesk@hmc.edu.

Should the need arise, [CIS](https://cis.upenn.edu/) will assist [Facilities and Maintenance (F&M)](https://www.facilities.upenn.edu/) in the relocation of your IT related equipment. This could include your workstation, monitor, printers, etc.
F&M will contact CIS to disconnect your equipment and F&M will relocate it. After relocation, CIS will re-connect your equipment and test for functionality. Available to faculty and staff at HMC. In order to initiate the process, please contact Facilities and Maintenance to create a work order with them.
F&M will then reach out to CIS for the IT related portion of the request.

Zoom is a videoconferencing system that allows for online video meetings. It has features such as screen sharing, recording, breakout rooms, and a virtual whiteboard. At HMC, there is an institutional license that covers faculty, staff, and students. Zoom can also be integrated with Sakai for a more seamless view of class sessions. You can find more information about this integration in the guide to Zoom Integration with Sakai. Zoom is available to all HMC faculty, staff, and students. To access Zoom services using the new Harvey Mudd College vanity URL  enter username@hmc.edu.
When accessing Zoom for the first time via the HMC vanity URL,  and preferring to continue using an existing Zoom account like username@g.hmc.edu,  you will be presented with two options:
Update Email Address
Consolidate into Account
We recommend Update Email Address to retain your meetings and settings.
To access Zoom services using Zoom’s generic URL you may also use your username@hmc.edu and choose Sign-In With SSO.  The company domain name is hmc-edu.
If you have decided to continue with a Zoom account and username from before the activation of the HMC campus agreement, like username@g.hmc.edu please choose Sign In With Google for access.
More information about the HMC Zoom license and accounts, including some troubleshooting tips, can be found in our documentation on HMC Zoom Licensing and Accounts.
